results.title: William Harvey & the circulation of the blood
results.brief_description: A detailed informative film of Harvey’s progressive studies and experiments arriving at his conclusions relative to the present day.

results.title: Turandot
results.creator_credit: Harold Prince, Rodney Greenberg and Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen
results.brief_description: Music by Giacomo Puccini with libretto by Giuseppe Adami and Renato Simoni, this made for television performance of “Turandot” was staged at the wonderfully atmospheric Vienna State Opera in 1983 under the exciting direction of Harold Prince (stage) and Rodney Greenberg (television). Set in Peking in legendary times, “Turandot” is a tale of drama, love and fantasy and of a Princess out to seek revenge on behalf of her ancestor Princess Lou-Ling who was brutally slain by a conquering prince. Turandot’s (Eva Marton) loathing and disdain for men brings about a proclamation that she will only become the bride of the royal suitor who can successfully answer three riddles. However, unsuccessful suitors will lose not only the hand of the princess, but also their heads. Enter a handsome young stranger by the name of Prince Calaf (Jose Carreras) who, although strongly discouraged by Turandot’s ministers, Ping (Robert Kerns), Pang (Helmut Wildhaber) and Pong (Heinz Zednik), is so overcome with Turandot’s beauty, that he offers himself as a new suitor. The story twists and turns until it reaches its tumultuous climactic end. Featuring stunning costumes in brilliant colors and spectacular stage sets, and supported by the Vienna State Opera Orchestra and Chorus conducted by world-renowned Lorin Maazel, this adaptation of “Turandot” is quite a visual experience. The internationally acclaimed lead singers each put in a magnificent performance and are strongly supported by Waldemar Kmentt (Altoum, Emperor of China), John Paul Bogart (Timur, vanquished King of Tartary) and Katia Ricciarelli (Liu the slave girl). Sung in Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Turn of the tide. The Man at the gate
results.creator_credit: Norman Walker, J. Arthur Rank, John Corfield, Lady Yule and British National Films GHW Productions
results.brief_description: Turn of the tide (80 min): This rarely seen British film, based on the novel ‘Three fevers’ by Leo Walmsley, was filmed on location at Robin Hood’s Bay and Whitby and tells the story of rivalry between two fishing families. It is set in the dramatically beautiful countryside of the Yorkshire coast. “The Man at the gate” (48 min): In 1940 Norman Walker put on his sea boots yet again and sent his location team down to Cornwall to shoot exteriors for a film which might have been regarded as a sequel. The story is centred around a fishing family, headed by Wilfrid Lawson.

results.title: Turn of the century
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A glance at Canada’s yesteryears, at people and events, fashions and foibles at the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th. From old photos and fragments of silent movies, this film pieces together a lively chronicle of what our elders like to call “the good old days.”

results.title: Turkey: the bridge
results.creator_credit: Derek Williams, British Petroleum and Samaratin Films
results.brief_description: Traces the history of Turkey - the land bridge between Europe and Asia. For more than 3,000 years the great events of these two continents centred on Turkey. The remains of the Greek civilisation, the crusades, and ancient Constantinople are contrasted with scenes of modern Istanbul.

results.title: Tumanu's people
results.creator_credit: John Morris, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Documents Commonwealth Government assistance to the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory in 1960. Shows the contrast between the old aboriginal way of life, which is gone for ever and the new. Stresses the progress made over recent years, the difficulties of older people adjusting to big changes and how the children will be those to enjoy the new life.

results.title: Weekend at Bernies (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Ted Kotcheff, Victor Drai, Gladden Entertainment and Rank Film Productions
results.brief_description: Larry and Richard have just discovered a fraud and embezzlement scheme that’s costing the insurance company they work for millions. Their Mafia connected boss Bernie is behind the crime and invites them for a weekend so he can rub them out. After some major bungling, it’s Bernie who ends up dead and Larry and Richard have to convince everyone Bernie is alive. As the tagline states, “for a corpse, Bernie sure gets around.” Cast includes Andrew McCarthy, Jonathan Silverman, Catherine Mary Stewart and Terry Kiser.

results.title: Wedlock: a satirical fantasy
results.creator_credit: Ed Spiegel and Louis Clyde Stoumen
results.brief_description: A fantasy which satirises the obscure symbolism of some “experimental” films. Skilled montage of quite disconnected shots adds up to excitement, and often to irony. However, the theme of disenchantment in marriage is treated only lightly, and is soon lost in a desire to exploit the effects of seeping, oozing liquids, intercut with portraits of problem people.

results.title: Turandot
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Giuliano Montaldo, National Video Corporation, Radiotelevisione Italiana and Radio Televisione Svizzera Italiana (RTSI)
results.brief_description: Giacomo Puccini’s opera Turandot, with libretto by Giuseppe Adami and Renato Simoni, tells the legend of the beautiful but icy Princess Turandot, and the three riddles she asked her would-be suitors. Performed at the Arena di Verona in 1983 by the Orchestra, Chorus and Corps de Ballet of the Arena di Verona this lavish production with its epic stage setting and beautiful hues of pastel colors features a wonderful cast with Ghena Dimitrova as Turandot, Nicola Martinucci as Prince Calaf, Cecilia Gasia as Liu, Ivo Vinco as Timur. Produced by Giuliano Montaldo, conducted by Maurizio Arena. Sung in Italian. Includes a guide with English translation.
